newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crudes drift lower, Sep/Oct roll gains late.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crudes drift lower, Sep/Oct roll gains late.

text.p: U.S. crudes drifted lower in sympathy with declining spot values, though grades gained some strength to the close, traders said Wednesday.
Business was subdued, however, as September business was in the process of being cleared up, leaving many to take to the sidelines ahead of more serious October supplies.
The September/October West Texas Intermediate roll widened in the afternoon, gaining around 15-20 cents to end in a 40-45 cents range, lifting Postings Plus to $2.10-$2.20.
Sep WTI/Cushing ended the session weaker at $22.10-$22.20, and Oct WTI/Cushing at $21.75-$21.80.

Outright crude prices were pushed some 30-40 cents lower on the day due to pressure from morning stock data, which showed a higher crude build in U.S. government numbers than the weekly American Petroleum Institute (API) report Tuesday.
Support for prices was seen when Mexican state oil company PEMEX said it shut all three ports in the Gulf of Mexico as a precaution against Tropical Storm Dolly.
More than 800,000 barrels a day (bpd) of crude oil exports to the U.S. stand to be delayed, traders said.
Grades firmed, however, as the session dragged on, but overall the prices were steady to slightly off from Tuesday.
Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James saw late trades at 16 and 17 cents over WTI/Cushing, then fell back by the close.
Midland/WTI was around the even level to WTI/Cushing, with Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire also hovering at that mark.
Sour grades saw deals for West Texas Sour/Midland at minus $1.50 to WTI/Cushing, and was talked at minus $1.55-$1.45.
Late deals in the Brent aftermarket saw two full cargoes exchanged at $20.30 for October paper, 9 cents above the IPE Brent close. The Sep/Oct Brent spreads were sold at 50 cents.
Foreign crude business into the U.S. was quiet. Brent cargoes remained in an unfavorable light under current arbitrage conditions, traders said.
